title: PhantomData<T> doesn't trigger improper_ctypes_definitions lint

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org -->

```rust
use std::marker::PhantomData;

#[repr(C)]
struct Ptr<T> {
    ptr: *const T,
    _phantom: PhantomData<T>,
}

extern "C" fn test(ptr: Ptr<String>) {}
```

Based on the documentation of [`PhantomData`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/marker/struct.PhantomData.html):
> Adding a PhantomData<T> field to your type tells the compiler that your type acts as though it stores a value of type T, even though it doesn’t really.

I would think that it should trigger the `improper_ctypes_definitions` compiler lint, like this example would:

```rust
#[repr(C)]
struct Ptr<T> {
    inner: T
}

extern "C" fn test(ptr: Ptr<String>) {}
```

```rust
warning: `extern` fn uses type `String`, which is not FFI-safe
 --> src/lib.rs:6:25
  |
6 | extern "C" fn test(ptr: Ptr<String>) {}
  |                         ^^^^^^^^^^^ not FFI-safe
  |
  = note: `#[warn(improper_ctypes_definitions)]` on by default
  = help: consider adding a `#[repr(C)]` or `#[repr(transparent)]` attribute to this struct
  = note: this struct has unspecified layout
```

I think that it is intuitive that `PhantomData<T>` should be marked as not FFI-safe if `T` is not FFI-safe.

There is a workaround to this by using `[T; 0]` instead of `PhantomData<T>`, but it is very hacky:

```rust
#[repr(C, packed)]
struct PhantomType<T>([T; 0]);

#[repr(C)]
struct Ptr<T> {
    ptr: *const T,
    _phantom: PhantomType<T>,
}

extern "C" fn test(ptr: Ptr<String>) {} // gives warning
```
